stem: The nurse is evaluating the developmental milestones of four infants during routine check-ups. Based on the assessment findings documented in the EHR, match each infant's observed behavior to the expected age range.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
**08:00** SBAR for Infant A: 6-month-old presenting for routine check-up. Mother reports infant is able to roll from stomach to back and is starting to sit with support. Infant vocalizes with babbling sounds. No known allergies. 

**08:30** SBAR for Infant B: 12-month-old presenting for routine check-up. Parents report infant pulls to stand and cruises along furniture. Infant responds to simple requests and uses 'mama' and 'dada' nonspecifically. No known allergies.

**09:00** SBAR for Infant C: 18-month-old presenting for routine check-up. Mother reports toddler walks independently and attempts to feed self with a spoon. Toddler speaks several single words and points to objects when named. No known allergies.

**09:30** SBAR for Infant D: 12-month-old presenting for routine check-up. Father reports infant sits unsupported for several minutes, reaches for toys with one hand, and transfers objects from one hand to the other. Infant babbles and imitates sounds. No known allergies.

**10:00** SBAR for Infant E: 18-month-old presenting for routine check-up. Mother reports toddler walks independently, scribbles with crayons, and drinks from a cup. Toddler uses 10-15 single words and follows simple commands. No known allergies.

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content:
Infant A (6 months): HR 130 bpm, RR 30, Temp 99.0°F (37.2°C), SpO2 98%
Infant B (12 months): HR 120 bpm, RR 24, Temp 98.6°F (37.0°C), SpO2 99%
Infant C (18 months): HR 110 bpm, RR 22, Temp 98.4°F (36.9°C), SpO2 99%
Infant D (12 months): HR 125 bpm, RR 26, Temp 98.8°F (37.1°C), SpO2 98%
Infant E (18 months): HR 105 bpm, RR 20, Temp 98.2°F (36.8°C), SpO2 99%

tabs.title: Lab Results
tabs.content: All infants have lab results within normal limits for their respective age groups. Hemoglobin, hematocrit, and white blood cell counts are all within expected ranges.

tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content:
Infant A: Alert, active, good muscle tone. Anterior fontanel open.
Infant B: Alert, active, good muscle tone. Plantar grasp reflex fading.
Infant C: Alert, active, good muscle tone. Demonstrates pincer grasp.
Infant D: Alert, active, good muscle tone. Negative Babinski reflex.
Infant E: Alert, active, good muscle tone. Able to stack two blocks.

tabs.title: Care Plan
tabs.content: Routine well-child check-up. Administer scheduled vaccines per age-appropriate immunization schedule. Provide anticipatory guidance regarding nutrition, safety, and developmental milestones.

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content: Vaccines administered per schedule: Infant A - DTaP, Hib, Polio, PCV13, Rotavirus; Infant B - MMR, Varicella, HepA; Infant C - HepA booster; Infant D - MMR, Varicella, HepA; Infant E - HepA booster.

rows.text: Infant A: Rolls from stomach to back, babbles, sits with support.
Infant B: Pulls to stand, cruises, responds to simple requests, uses 'mama' and 'dada' nonspecifically.
Infant C: Walks independently, attempts to self-feed, speaks several single words, points to objects.
Infant D: Sits unsupported, reaches for toys, transfers objects, babbles and imitates sounds.
Infant E: Walks independently, scribbles, drinks from a cup, uses 10-15 words, follows simple commands.

rationale.correct:
Infant A (6 months): At 6 months, infants typically roll from stomach to back, babble, and can sit with support.
Infant B (12 months): At 12 months, infants typically pull to stand, cruise along furniture, respond to simple requests, and use 'mama' and 'dada' nonspecifically.
Infant C (18 months): At 18 months, toddlers typically walk independently, attempt to self-feed, speak several single words, and point to objects when named.
Infant D (12 months): At 12 months, infants typically sit unsupported, reach for toys, transfer objects, and babble and imitate sounds.
Infant E (18 months): At 18 months, toddlers typically walk independently, scribble, drink from a cup, use 10-15 words, and follow simple commands.
rationale.incorrect: Incorrect matching would occur if the nurse associates behaviors with incorrect age ranges. For example, mistaking behaviors typical of a 6-month-old for an 18-month-old, or vice versa, would indicate a lack of understanding of developmental milestones.

answerBreakdown.text: Infant A: Rolls from stomach to back, babbles, sits with support.
answerBreakdown.rationale: Rolling, babbling, and sitting with support are expected milestones for a 6-month-old infant, correlating with typical motor and language development for this age.

answerBreakdown.text: Infant B: Pulls to stand, cruises, responds to simple requests, uses 'mama' and 'dada' nonspecifically.
answerBreakdown.rationale: Pulling to stand, cruising, responding to simple requests, and using 'mama' and 'dada' are expected milestones for a 12-month-old infant, indicating advancements in motor and language skills.

answerBreakdown.text: Infant C: Walks independently, attempts to self-feed, speaks several single words, points to objects.
answerBreakdown.rationale: Walking independently, attempting to self-feed, speaking several single words, and pointing to objects are expected milestones for an 18-month-old toddler, representing increased autonomy and communication abilities.

answerBreakdown.text: Infant D: Sits unsupported, reaches for toys, transfers objects, babbles and imitates sounds.
answerBreakdown.rationale: Sitting unsupported, reaching for toys, transferring objects, and babbling and imitating sounds are expected milestones for a 12-month-old infant, indicating coordination and early communication skills.

answerBreakdown.text: Infant E: Walks independently, scribbles, drinks from a cup, uses 10-15 words, follows simple commands.
answerBreakdown.rationale: Walking independently, scribbling, drinking from a cup, using 10-15 words, and following simple commands are expected milestones for an 18-month-old toddler, demonstrating greater independence and cognitive understanding.

clinicalPearls: Developmental milestones provide a framework for assessing a child's growth and development. Variations can be normal, but significant deviations warrant further investigation.
Early intervention is crucial for children with developmental delays to maximize their potential.
Parents should be educated on age-appropriate activities to promote their child's development.

questionTrap.trap: Confusing milestones across similar age ranges (e.g., 9 months vs. 12 months) due to overlapping skills.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Focus on the distinguishing skills for each age range, such as the level of independence in motor skills or the clarity and quantity of language used.

mnemonic.title: SMART Milestones
mnemonic.expansion: Specific milestones for each age; Measurable progress; Achievable skills; Relevant to age; Time-bound expectations.
